segments.text: Who's next guy's going to get shipped out?
And I had to clean out about half the instructors there before they got the idea that we were serious about this business.
And that you were going to have a technical and not a theoretical school.
And a technical school, yeah.
So that everybody was working on a breadboard or a piece of equipment.
And so...
it worked out pretty well.
And would you consider that was your main accomplishment down in Florida?
I would say that that was the main accomplishment down there, turning it around and making it into a practical type of school.
And did it change the quality of the student?
Well, everybody said so.
So you got a man who could really work on radar.
Yeah.
And it's amazing.
the individuals who had never had any responsibility except to fly airplanes, what kind of job they would do.
I mean, they really would jump in and really take over.
So about that time, the war was grinding down.
And I went off to be 29 in transition school.
Well, at the Florida, could you compare the size of this school, the radio school in Sioux Falls and the radar school in Florida?
How many men did you have under your command?
Oh, the number of students at the radar school is just about half of the number at the radio school.
And of course, the other thing at Boca Raton,
Florida is that every time they get a commander, he would get fired or get transferred.
I had more than a year and a half, I think, that I was there.
I was acting base commander longer than any guy that was stationed there.
What do you attribute that to?
Well, it was very, at that time it was very fluid because the individual, the senior officers who hadn't been overseas were being plucked out and sent overseas to get combat time.
Sure.
Why didn't they pluck you and send you off?
Well, I don't know.
I was one of these individuals.
Every time the training command got a directive to
increase their training program.
They always say they could do it provided this group of officers was retained in the training command.
And I was in that group that I was always on a list to go overseas, but never could go overseas because you're always increasing the training program.
Sure.
And when you went on, you were instructed not to fly on combat missions.
Yeah.
So when I went over that three-month break, you couldn't even fly on a combat mission because so many of them were getting shot down.
Exactly.
One last question before lunchtime.
You didn't see combat during the Second World War.
Well, I guess two questions.
One, do you think that had an effect on your career?
And two, were you disappointed?
Well, I was disappointed.
I don't think it had much to do with your career.
General Yowd, I was always chewing at the bet to get overseas.
You wrote letters to him.
General Yowd, who commanded the training command, he would always talk to him and say, the tanks are not going to make any difference whatsoever when this thing is over.
And General Arnold said not to ask anymore.
Yeah, because he said you were too valuable as to what you were doing.
But anyway, I got to Okinawa after the war was over, or about the time the war was over, and I went into Japan on September 11, 1945, which is only a few days after the surrender.
But it must have been sort of disappointing for a career man not to be able to, a career military man, not to see the actual combat.
Well.
He's forgotten how disappointing it was.
When he was sent off to England, you know, before we put in radar, he came back and put in the radar, the first radar, excuse me, did you tell him that?
Yeah, we did.
That's when they told me not to go on any combat missions because she had all the secrets and then he wanted to shut down.
Yeah.
Radar was, of course, a great technical advance during the Second World War, something that the Germans and the Japanese never got a hold of.
Was there a lot of security on the base, a lot of top secret?
Oh, yeah.
You had fences around all the buildings.
We wanted to go, but there were a lot of them that didn't get to go, just to get back around.
And you had guards on the gates, and you had passers, and that type of thing.
It was real interesting.
I mean, it was fascinating, really.
While at Boca Raton, I flew the B-17, and then I became a real proficient radar bomber, blind bomber.
on the Keys out in the Bahamas.
And that's where we were.
And you had a lot of, you sent students out, a lot of operations out there for radar bombing?
Yeah, well, see, we had, all I would say maybe 25 bombers, either B-17s or B-24s.
And we taught the bombardiers how to operate the equipment.
And when they would give up, I'd go down and
and work on the set, see if I could get it working.
Because you get out to the Bahamas, you're, whatever it is, an hour and a half, two hours out there.
And I got in a lot of radar bombing myself, so it became a very, and I flew twice a week on one of those planes.
So you got your flight time up.
Yeah, well in fact I got more time in the B-17 in one year that I flew.
at the same to me, around 300 hours.
Okay, let's stop and we'll talk about your post-war career.
Okay, this is a continuation of our interviews, and we were talking a couple of hours ago about
your role during the Second World War as director of first the Radio Technical School in South Dakota and then the Radar Technical School down in Florida.
I noticed that you were awarded the Legion of Merit Medal for outstanding leadership, organizational ability, and exceptionally notorious conduct in the performance of outstanding services.
Tell me about that.
I think I've already told you all about it.
Organizing the school at Sioux Falls, South Dakota.
Right.
It was because of that.
It was because of the organization.
And your radar school at Boca Raton, Florida.
And then of course establishing the various technical schools while I was at Scott.
Okay.
Let's continue then with your military career.
You went to Okinawa, or out to Japan in 1945 as subordinate commander and staff executive of the 5th Air Force.
You were there during the McCarthy years then.
Can you tell me about General MacArthur?
Well I admired the individual.
He's a very, was a very
I don't think that anyone else could have done the same job in Japan that he did.
They idolized the emperor and so they idolized him.
In fact the Japanese I think just stole the show from us.
What do you mean?
they, we'd probably, I don't know, probably Americans if we'd been occupied, why we'd probably, we'd probably have bombed everybody or shoot them, snipers, what have you.
Well the Japanese decided that, that well Americans must have something.
So they decided to
to see what we had, and they copied everything we had.
And this is quality control now.
Come in.
You were saying that MacArthur was the only one who could take care of that situation.
Well, I think that MacArthur was...
Well, I'd say egotistical enough to just fall into the Japanese pattern.
And the command, do you mean?
Yeah, as a command.
And his headquarters, why every day that he was normally left at a certain time, the Japanese would line the streets just to take a look at him.
Really?
Yeah.
And I think the Japanese figured that the Americans, to win the war over there, must have something.
So they're great copiers.
Oh, they sure are.
And I'm sure that they recognize that they're
Up until that time, I always considered Japanese products as junk.
And they produced the best cameras.
They produced the best TVs.
They produced the best automobiles.
I mean, their quality control is just outstanding, it seems to me.
And of course, I spent
four years in Japan.
Was MacArthur at that time your commanding officer then?
No, I was way down the line.
I started out to be in 5th Bomber Command where General Crabb was, Jimmy Crabb was the commander and then I moved to headquarters 5th Air Force and General Wolf was the commander.
Now he was 5th Air Force and then you had
the Far East Air Forces that was commanded by a lieutenant general, whereas 5th Air Force was a major general.
I was on the staff of 5th Air Force and then later I got a command of 315th Air Division.
Did you have an opportunity to meet General MacArthur?
Oh, yeah.
Oh, yeah.
In staff meetings, things like that?
No, no.
How?
No, well, mostly when you were on the staff, you were presenting plans of some sort to General MacArthur and his staff.
But he never inspected any of the bases at which I was located.
Most of it is more of a headquarters type of thing.
And I was trying to think of other occasions.
Most of the other occasions were social occasions, you know, where you attended something that you were invited to as a senior officer in the occupation forces.
What did other officers think of him?
Was there a general feeling?
Well, I think that there was always a general feeling of either you were for MacArthur or you were against MacArthur.
He was a controversial type of individual where he was always
when you landed on Okinawa, he was out there having his picture taken waving shore or something of this sort.
And I think the other thing that MacArthur, I think he had his wife with him almost all the time.
And of course everybody resented that type
If he had his wife with him, why couldn't everybody else have their wife with them?
What kind of relations did the occupation army have with the Japanese people?
Well, to start with, you had practically no relations at all.
When we first went in there, you had this little parrot type of
dictionary that you thumb through and try to get your directions.
And of course they were afraid of you.
I mean when you stopped to ask a question they would head off across the rice paddies.
And of course they were, we went into one of the
bases there.
We went in first to a big Japanese school and took that over.
Then we had a lot of Japanese workers working on base to clean it up and build the mess halls and this type of thing.
For your own troops?
For your own troops.
You were building a military base then, right?
Oh yeah.
And a training school, a technical school.

And then later on we moved up to Johnson and then all the experienced people who were there were rotated to the states and we got in a whole division of infantry and they were transferred to the Air Force and you just, they were riflemen and so you had a bunch of warm bodies and you had to
going to change them over into airplane mechanics and this type of thing.
So again, we established some of the same people I had in the technical schools.
I went through the records at the Far East Air Forces and located some of my instructors and technical officers that were in the technical schools back in the States, picked them up, and we
technical school.
We of course had lots of airplanes.
They were just destroying airplanes, American airplanes, brand new, crushing them up and dumping them at sea because you just didn't have any place to keep them.
Nor did you have any need for them.
So we got all kinds of airplanes, all kinds of engines, everything we needed as far as
mock-ups are concerned, but these people work on them, so it worked out pretty well.
I was also wondering about your feelings on dropping the atomic bomb.
As far as I was concerned, it was the right thing to do.
I mean, when you get into a situation like that, it's either us or them.
If you say, okay, we're not going
drop the atomic bomb and you lose 100,000 American soldiers occupying Japan.
It would have cost us dearly because everything underground was just like a beehive.
It's just like when we went into Okinawa.
of all kinds of caves.
They were dug in.
They were dug in.
They were ready for it.
As far as I was concerned, I feel like that's the right thing to do.
You can't look back.
Did you have an opportunity to travel much in the country?
Did you get down to Nagasaki or Hiroshima?
Yeah, I visited both Nagasaki and Hiroshima.
What did you see?
It was about like all the pictures that you see.
It was sometime after when I got down to Nagasaki and it had a zero, it had a stake of some sort, sign or something where the zero point where the bomb actually hit.
And they just cleaned everything up.
I mean they just leveled everything.
The firebombing did just as bad a damage, not the Okinawa, but all the cities.
The napalm bombing made by the B-29s, they gutted every city.
They certainly did, yeah.
Killed more than the atomic bombs.
That's right.
And you'd drive down the streets of almost any city in Japan, and tin and everything else was stacked up on the sidewalks, and you just had this one little alley to drive down the street.
So we did a good, I mean, the Air Force did a real good job, as far as saving American lives is concerned.
No question about that.
Also during this time that you were in Japan, 45 to 49, the Air Force became an independent organization shifting out of the United States Army.
What were your feelings on that as a West Point graduate?
Well, I don't know.
I thought it was all right.
I jumped from a permanent captain to a permanent colonel.
when I transferred.
Couldn't beat that.
Couldn't beat that at all.
And I was a temporary colonel, so I went to a permanent colonel.
And then I was on a board interviewing all the
Air Corps people and the Army people who wanted to transfer to the Air Force as a selection board.
And so we interviewed a lot of people who wanted to transfer.
If you didn't want to transfer, you'd go back to the Army.
You didn't have to transfer to the Air Force.
In other words, enlisted men?
No, officers, mostly officers.
officers who were in the United States Army, but who had Air Force related jobs?
Jobs are, if you didn't have Air Force related jobs.
Oh, they just wanted to get into the Air Force.
Why is that?
Because promotions were obviously going to be good?
Well, I don't know, maybe some of them felt that the Air Force was much like the Navy.
I mean, they always had a better living than the infantrymen in the trenches.
But most of them were doctors who didn't make any difference whether or not you were in the Army or the Air Force.
Ordinance specialists that both of us required.
And personnel, administration, any of those.
And then, of course, some of the non-rated people wanted to become rated, and they were also transferred into the Air Force.
So what did you look for on the board?
I mean, what qualities did you look for?
What kind of man did you want to be an Air Force officer?
Well, the first thing you look at is their shoes.
I mean, you look at their personal appearance.
And it was amazing at the time that some people would come before a board in combat boots that had mud all over them and things of that sort.
And the guy was dressed up who was looking sharp who answered our
and all you were trying to do is get them to talk.
You really didn't have any specific questions.

What you wanted to know is how they expressed themselves and they were, I don't know, I can't remember a couple of pointed questions that we'd ask them, but most of it was just a matter of getting them to express themselves, what their objective was in an Air Force career and how they looked.
If they dressed up,
cleanly shaven, hair cut, shoes shined, and under the conditions over there, a reasonably pressed pair of pants, you normally accepted them.
And you accepted, I'd say you probably accepted 75%.
Was there a lot of, during this time when the Air Force was breaking away from the Army, was there a lot of inter-service rivalry?
Do you remember any incidents of that?
No, I don't.
I don't always think of an incident where the Army, when I commanded the 315th Air Division, my division commander's wife was at the commissary and my wife was standing in line to
check out while she waltzes right through ahead of everybody and apparently the guy on the check out counter says, well that's Mrs. Hetherington back there.
She's the wife of the 3853rd Division Commander and apparently Mrs. Blanchard.
I said, well, I don't care.
But that's about the only instance I can remember.
But no, I mean, you had, there wasn't really, as far as I was concerned, there really wasn't a lot of, and you really didn't have that much contact with them.
Because you played them, each division had their own football team.
Sure.
and you played them, so there's a lot of rivalry as far as football was concerned, but there's a lot of rivalry between this Army division and another one, the 8th Cavalry and somebody else.
But in the colonel ranks of Army people or Navy people over there, people got along.
Oh yeah, see everybody was promoted.
Like in my class of 33, everybody was promoted at the same time.
I was promoted to first lieutenant and then I was promoted to captain.
All my classmates were promoted to captain at the same time.
and same thing the Majors, same thing the Lieutenant Colonel.

And then after that it was a selection process whether or not you were overseas in combat where your chances of getting promoted head kind of a field promotion was greater than you were if you were working back in the States.
But about every six months I got promoted.
There was another aspect during the Truman administration.
Not only did he take the Air Force and change the Department of Defense, or establish the Department of Defense, but also he had an executive order in 1948 that integrated the services.
Do you remember if that had any, do you remember when the first Air Force units when you were in Japan were integrated?
No, we didn't have, it just wasn't that many colored troops that were available to, to, in fact I don't, I don't, I don't think we had to pop it off.
I mean I don't,
I don't think we got a single colored pilot or what have you.
It took, well I'll say it, when I commanded Massawa a long time later, why did you have a really integrated command?
And I would say after graduating from the Air War College and commanding the security service, you had a few colored troops, but not very many.
So you didn't get any...
It really wasn't a problem.
Okay, okay.
Now let's talk about your command of the 315th Wing.
What were your functions and duties there?
Well, I had...
I think about four bases underneath me.
I had a 38th bomb wing and I had an 8th fighter group and I had an air command, an ACNW outfit, that's the air command and warning system.
I would say the biggest problem I had there was that I was junior to a lot of colonels.
You mean you were a lieutenant colonel?
No, I was junior in grade as far as seniority was concerned.
And those guys, I figured they gave me trouble all the time.
Oh, they did?
Well, they didn't really support you like they would have if they'd been junior to you.

So other commanders of other wings, then, in other words, the relationship between you and other commanders wasn't very good because they received Well, I commanded 315th, and then I had the commander of Inazuki Base.
was senior to me and the commander of the 38th bomb group was senior to me.
And then the 8th fire group commander was junior to me.
And I think I had three colonels that were commanders.
And I was designated commander by the election of the president.
And of course, I think your biggest problem in those conditions is trying to be a nice guy rather than really clamping down.
And either insisting that they do what you want them to, and want it done, and want things done, or quit.
One of them got to drinking too much.
